Description: (Information relating to an identifiable person e.g. names, ID numbers,location data)
(Any operation performed on personal data e.g. collection, storage)
(Freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous consent)
(Data concerning racial/ethnic origin, political opinions, religious beliefs, health)
(Personal data must be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary)
(Collected for specified, explicit, and legitimate purposes)
Personal data must be accurate and kept up-to-date
Personal data should be kept only as long as necessary
(Appropriate measures to prevent unauthorized access loss or disclosure)
Right to know what personal data is being processed and why
Right to correct inaccurate or incomplete data
Right to request deletion of data under specific conditions
Right to limit the processing of personal data
(Right to receive personal data in a structured machine-readable format)
Right to object to data processing for legitimate reasons
Right not to be subject to automated decision-making and profiling
Entity determining the purposes and means of processing personal data
Entity processing data on behalf of the controller
Obligation to maintain records of all processing activities
Required when processing is likely to result in high risk to individuals' rights
Obligation to report data breaches to the supervisory authority within 72 hours
Organizations must appoint a DPO if their processing activities meet certain criteria
Processing is lawful when the data subject has given consent
Processing necessary for the performance of a contract
Processing necessary to comply with a legal obligation
Processing necessary for legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party
Independent authorities monitoring compliance with GDPR
Penalties for non-compliance can reach up to 20 million EUR or 4% of global turnover
